content:
Fabian N. said:

Thanks! Wasn't subscribed and it didn't show up in the sidebar search. I'm new to this. :grimacing:

There's perhaps a UI bug here, in that the "Search streams" box isn't clear that it's only searching the listed streams you are already subscribed to, not all of them. I think it's an eminently reasonable assumption, confronted with a "Search streams" UI element, that it searches all of them.
I think the label is wrong -- that should be "Filter streams".
I'm going to attempt an audit for similar label issues -- when we mean "filter", we should say that.
In fact, the tooltip on the :magnifying_glass: says "Filter streams" already. It's just the placeholder.
I'm not sure what to do about the right sidebar -- we have "Filter users" as the title and "Search people" as the placeholder and USERS as the headline.
"Search" is accurate -- since by default we only display a subset of active users in large organizations like this one.
But we should probably settle on "People" vs "Users". I think there's a good argument for "people" in the sense that bot users will never appear in the sidebar.
I'd say Search as you would be searching for a specific someone rather than filtering.
Well, I think the key difference is that "Filter" will never return something that's not visible before your filter.
And our right sidebar can find users who are not by default visible, so "search" is more appropriate there.
Slack uses "People", though mostly it avoids the term altogether in favor of @someone. Cursor_and_Slack___Composer___Gimlet_Members.png
Discord has "user", though most places in the UI use other terms like "member" or some community-specific designation. _announcements.png
I have a mild vote for "People", but no strong preference other than consistency.
Member has a role meaning for us as well.
Should we change the tooltip in he right sidebar to say "Search people", matching the placeholder text in the search box?
Yes, those should have the same text.
